reviewText:
Wurm Unlimited really is a game unlike any other in feel. When it says you can go anywhere and do it; you can. Now that the game is available off of the official servers it takes that tagline and runs even further with it. This offline version will not only offer the go anywhere, do anything mentality it will also offer moddability and innovation.

The game is written in Java and the code is thus far unobfuscated. This means that any modding community that crops up, and we're already seeing a seed of one, will be able to expand relatively unfettered. This means a lot for the longevity of the game, which by the way is already monumental (the online version has existed for a decade), will stretch even further. It will also allow for advances in approachability for the uninitiated.

The game itself is by first definition; relaxing. It lacks the fast paced motifs and get-stoned-by-some-naked-dude-as-a-fresh-spawn mentality of other games of this type. It also lacks cutting edge graphics, but the graphics it does present are relatively clean and playable. I see some beauty in it and you can too if you just look at the screenshots. This also allows for the game to run on older systems. The game also lacks smooth animations, but the animations that do exist get the point across.

The game's main to dos are listed in the various trailers and description. A lot of it fails to mention the passable magic/faith system in the game that takes it from just a medieval todo to a more fantasy one. Also, the dragons, fiends, giant spiders, and hellthings help move that along.

The game as of now offers two modes. An Adventure mode which I would recemmond to new players as it bundles in a tutorial, and a creative" mode which uses the term not like that certain world-renowned voxel game
date: but in the sense that the land is virgin and it is up to you and/or your friends to shape it. The adventure has some prebuilt areas and will guide you through the shallows of the game.\n\nOverall Wurm is a game similar to many
hoursPlayed: and the first of it's kind by age

reviewText:
Oh, man. . . . Wurm Unlimited. Where the heck do I start?

So here are the pros/cons of Wurm Online, then I'll do pros/cons of Wurm Unlimited.

Wurm Online:

Pros
1) The game is more realistic in terms of crafting, skilling, etc. than any game I've ever come across.
2) A sense of accomplishment is just around the corner as you build up your character, your deed, or just run off exploring all over the beautiful landscape.
3) Many will disagree with this, but I think the graphics are a 'pro' for me. I really enjoy the graphics. It's not crazy, but they aren't Minecraft. It is a gorgeous game, in my opinion.
4) The freedom you get in the game is astonishing and absolutely mind-boggling.
5) Just one more plank.
6) Okay, okay, just one more.
7) Ya' know what, I'll just finish this wall.

Cons
1) For most people, the menus/submenus will be a red 'x' against the game. But honestly, most things are intuitive (use a saw on a log and you'll make things that you would if you were using a saw on a log in RL).
2) HUGE learning curve (although once you learn how to play, you're like 'duh..that makes sense').
3) Fighting anything, especially early on in your Wurm life, can take for-EVER!!! This has always been a detractor for me in the game. That said, I must also note that once you obtain a decent QL (quality) weapon with some nice enchants, the battles are pretty quick, but getting the silver to buy such weapons will take a lot of work!
4) Just one more plank.
5) Okay, okay, just one more!
6) Ya' know what? I'll just finish this house.

Wurm Unlimited

Pros
1) It's friggin' singleplayer if you want! Take all of the pros from above and plop them down into a singleplayer mode where you can be a GM and fart around on a server! For a lot of players, this is just what they were looking for!

2) No subscription needed and there are tons of servers available - including my own -- Taking Without Constent Dedicated 24/7 -- no subscription needed with the same awesome community-driven action!

3) The GMs of the online servers for Wurm Unlimited are going to be able to help you much more than they ever would on Wurm Online! Your experience could be free from some of the most frustrating aspects of the game if you choose the right server to play on!

Cons

1) They changed the way skills are gained and it was a pretty gnarly overhaul. Funny because I didn't think it could be as big of a change, but after playing for 100+ hours, it was a big change. The only con here, however, is the fact that the GM has to constantly tweak the settings to get it close to being realistic, but not annoying (especially the farming).

2) The rest are just the same as for Wurm Online.

Overall, this game is simply amazing. When I get on, I get lost in the Wurm world. I'm a GM now and am hosting my server through Citadel, and I must say, it's awesome to have an investment into the game like I have now. And if you're looking for a great server that will be focused on community, and alleviating a lot of annoyances in the game, look no further than TWOC - Taking Without Consent.

reviewText:
Out of all the sandbox, crafting, building, multiplayer games I've played, this one was my biggest disappointment. And, if you don't try playing this game, you are missing out on one of the best fantasy building/crafting games ever.

I dedicated 440 hours in 48 days to this game. I started playing Oct. 29th. At first I didn't get what made the game so good, but as I kept playing I began to understand that it is unique and fun. I built mines, roads, houses, farms, a blacksmith, an inn, a bakery and other shops, a dock with ships, tons of tools and furniture, bred horses, sheep and cared for other animals, including a brown bear which was my mount. I eventually rented a Wurm Server so that my friends and I could all play together. As I said, if you like medieval fantasy crafting games, this game is the best one I've played. What's nice is that you can set your own personal configuration settings for your world to make the experience feel less of a grind. Doing so helps to speed up progress. I did a x15 skill gain, with a x3 action multiplier.

I suppose my situation was unfortunate. I often found myself playing the game alone. Here I had this beautiful town taking shape, but no one to see it. It was like living in a ghost town. I did have some playtime with a few friends, but everyone was busy building their own settlements. I felt I was the only one who'd occasionally visit the other settlements to admire progression.

It was disheartening that my Wurm Unlimited experience did not go as I expected. I had hoped to get more out of the multiplayer aspect than I did. It is such a great game, albeit the graphics and animations are outdated.

Try the game. If you're playing with friends, stick together. Make one settlement. Build a community. Explore the world together. There's potential for a great experience.

reviewText:
I love this game.  That said, there are some things you should know before you buy it, or else you set yourself up for disappointment.  Most of the negative reviews are from people who didn't know these things before they purchased the game.  That just means the game wasn't meant for them, not that there's anything wrong with the game.

First, and most importantly, this game does not hold your hand and guide you through how to play.  Exploration and discovery are part of the game by design.  You get a few popup messages explaining some basic concepts, but then you're on your own.  Plan on spending a healthy amount of time on the Wurmpedia looking up how things work, or you will find yourself disappointed and frustrated.  Alternatively, if you like a challenge, it's possible to discover how things work on your own by trial and error, but not many people can do that.

Second, the graphics are not visually impressive.  Some of the graphics are from as long ago as 2006.  They serve a function, and that's it.  If you buy this game expecting AAA modern graphics, you will be disappointed.  Don't expect much from the graphics.

Third, this game is *deep* and can be overwhelming for some.  If you get the chance, take a look at the Skills window and browse through the list.  Every one of those skills is implemented into the game and affects what you can do in it.  There are also a few actions that don't have an associated skill.  If I haven't convinced you to devote time to browsing the Wurmpedia already, this is a very good reason to do that.

Finally, this game is about survival in a medieval fantasy setting, not about action.  Don't expect much from combat.  Combat is pretty much just targeting something and just making sure you're the right distance from the target to effectively fight.  Instead, enter the game with the expectation that you'll have to work" towards building your home and training hard enough to put up a fight against hungry spiders

reviewText:
I've played Wurm Online on and off since about 2006. My only gripe with the online version back then was the absolutely horrific graphics and the fact that a good 80-90% of the map was populated with people's old ♥♥♥♥, so it was very difficult to carve out a niche for yourself in all that.

What Code Club AB have done by releasing Wurm as a standalone version is nothing short of amazing. This game planted the seed in Notch's mind for Minecraft, and in itself is a much more complex, deep and time consuming game with much the same premise: exist and thrive in an empty world.

But the only real similarity that Minecraft and Wurm share here that I want to bring attention to is the core principle of the entire game: Teamwork and creativity.

You can terraform, build a house, tame animals, fight monsters, craft armour and weapons, and even commit yourself to one of the two religions in the game, but it does take a lot of time and a lot of teamwork. Whether that's something you find appealing or cannot stand, there is grinding in this game. But it's a grind that pays off with legendary tales and a real world that you strived to construct from nothing.

If one were to take even a cursory glance at Wurm Online's colourful history, they would find a completely player driven lore comprised of the rise and fall of empires, epic constructions of vast cities and trade highways, and to me, that highlights what Wurm is: stories. Being a part of something bigger. Helping to construct something lasting that you know took a lot of time and effort between friends.

With the release of the standalone version comes the chance for everyone to be a part of their own player driven history. While the MMO version has only a limited amount of resources and space for only so many cities and empires, this is not so for Unlimited. There's also the potential for mods and an ever increasing skill set for even more stuff to build and do in the game.  The possibilities truly are unlimited.

While I hesitate to draw more comparisons to Minecraft, I think for the benefit of the layman it'd be fair to say something like: In Minecraft you can create a house and perhaps even a town in the span of a day; it's really not a big deal and even less of an accomplishment. In Wurm, when you crest a hill and find a city that is truly impressive, you can count on the fact that a lot of people were here and they worked very hard to create it. That itself lends appeal to people who find enjoyment in coming together and working to build something cool. And whether it's a lone shack in the middle of the woods or an epic castle that you've just completed, the satisfaction of striving to build something from nothing is what keeps people coming back.

reviewText:
Finally, wurm without the harsh, limiting and overburdening rule set. Wurm Online could have been so much more had they just cut out a tad bit of the grind.

Not asking for theme-park hold your hand stuff. Just a game where you don't have to tab out and watch netflix because skilling up is so stupidly boring.

Well, now you don't have to play that way. You can set the skills how you want and be rid of the grip the 'dev' had over the game.

Wurm is worth a buy if you love being a settler and surviving and the wilds. Turn the music off for some amazing atmosphere and immersion.  Birds chirping, the hum of the waters, and someone in the distance destroying that stump...

Find a good community and/or meet new people, with 3x or more skill gains you wont have to worry about being glued to that forge for hours just to get one skill up.

That is what it's all about folks, Wurm Online glued you to the forge or other menial tasks and prevented you from going nomad or exploring proper. This game does not do that, you set the pace, you decided and find out why this game is peaceful and enjoyable.

reviewText:
This game proves you don't need fancy graphics to make an addicting game, that's full of creativity and keeps you going. Today's Sandbox survival games get to the point where you are bored. This game: you don't get bored. You rage hard, but you play to beat the challenge. Even from initial start point, you are basically under pressure to survive. Granted new servers will have starter areas, but beyond those walls you are at the bottom of the food chain.

By Bottom of the Food chain, I mean the fantasy creatures in this game: Large spiders, ugly trolls and hell hounds are always present when you feel safe. You need to beat the odds of even making it to a decent location: Hills, Swamps, Dense forests etc.

THIS GAME IS NOT FOR EVERYONE. This game places you in such a bad position, you need to think and act strategically to stay alive. If you do die, you suffer for it: You lose skill points.

I recommend this game based on it's challenge and complexity. No other game compares to it.
voteText: 62 of 71 people (87%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I tried to like this. I couldn't. I like sandboxes and love them when they have the potential for long term persistent change.
This had some micromanaging at the start just to survive your first few nights. That in itself was extremely time consuming and difficult but I like a little challenge.
Made a server, slightly inflated rates. Ok let's do this.

I eventually found out this relationship wasn't going to happen.
User vs UI: You have to right click or go into menus for nearly everything. There is no left-click = use tool. You have to queue up several actions and your character statistics throttle this. It also doesn't help that the game has a built-in wiki that it encourages you to use for every single item.
There is no tutorial.
Fighting a wild cat of really low level took half an hour and 3 retreats to heal up. Even then the combat log was saying barely poked" or "hardly scratched" which wasn't very reassuring.
Trying to get started with the 'first night essentials' was taking the greater part of two hours.
Could hardly make tools as you have a percentage based failure rate in proportion to low crafting skill.

On top of that Java loved to hang and crash.

This game is meant for a large persistent community with people religiously returning on a daily basis to get things done. You would only begin to experience what the game has to offer when you have a constant flow of over 16 people working together. There is no going lone wolf and expecting to get a small start to eventually bring people on or become accepted to a group. You need a team and you need people as a single person at starting rank cannot do anything within a reasonable time frame.
Tales of other players explain that they spent months or even years of repeated returns to the game just to spend a lot of time and feel 'rewarded'. It's at this point where the game seems more like a second job than just having fun for a little bit.
So for a short pick up and go this is definitely not the game you are looking for.
If you like convoluted UI with tons of clicking and days or weeks waiting from queued up actions then this is it.

I don't mind a bit of a grind but this was way too much for my patience
date: so I can't recommend this title.\n"

I'm writing this review based on two things:
- My 4+ years of playing Wurm Online
- The 16 hours I have played Wurm Unlimited

To start, Wurm is one of the best games I have ever played. The community in Wurm Online was always great, minus a few griefers here and there. It has one of the most in-depth crafting systems I have ever seen. And what makes it even better is that you can do anything you want to the world. Want to flatten that mountain or hill over there? Do it! (Although it might take you a while). Want to build a large canal connecting two bodies of water? You can do that! Want to convert a scorpion covered desert into a lush green forest? That can be done. This is probably the single most important reason I stuck with Wurm Online for so long.

Another thing I like about Wurm is the graphics. Yes, I know some of you are thinking How can you like the graphics?".. But it's not so much about comparing it to current game graphics

reviewText:
You think you have what it takes to make it in this Sandbox?  Prove it!

Wurm Unlimited, a version of both Client and Server, where you can run your own dedicated server locally and play in Adventure mode or host a server online for friends, family and guildmates.

All the goodness of Wurm in yours hands to do as you see fit.  Don't like the Wurm Online [the online run MMO] slow skill gains?  Pump up that multiplier!  Don't want to worry about settlement upkeep?  Uncheck that box.  Want to be a god among men?  Yep, you heard it right; give yourself max skills and GM tools/commands.

I've only played Wurm Online for a few months but my time had been both glorious and humbling.  Now I can share this with my growing son's who really have never experienced a true Sandbox as this.  Think they can make it out in the world?  Who knows but Wurm will teach them both victory and defeat and as they say it's not losing that defines a person; it's the ability to get back up and try again.

Huzzah!

reviewText: If you're looking for a game with serious depth in crafting and environment while willing to sacrifice a few aspects of today's twitch combat system then Wurm Unlimited is the game for you.  I've been playing Wurm Online for several years now and I always joke that it is my PvP Retirement Home
date:
but truthfully even the PvP systems are well above and beyond most mainstream MMOs.  The ability to customize your server settings mean you can tweak your specific server to find the balance you want between epic PvE encounters and faction based PvP warfare.

Dedicated servers are able to handle upwards of 200 players spread throughout kilometers of land with the ability to link servers together.  One of the most interesting features of Unlimited is that you can link severs together as 'neighbors' in order to travel from one map to the other with the ability to set up Home Kingdoms for people to build themselves up on and then travel to open warfare servers via ship.

Wurm Online is one of the only games that allows such a wide freedom of construction options while tying in boats, siege weapons, taming, deep crafting, extensive wound systems, religions, factions and a whole lot more.

The biggest downside is the archaic feeling combat system, but it does make up for it in the complexity of the way combat is calculated and the wide spectrum of options to include mounted, ranged, melee, pets and siege warfare.

The graphics have also come a long way since the MMOs inception and the viewing distance can make for some epic landscapes and vistas.

Overall, the game has a lot of depth if that is what you're seeking and if it feels intimidating there is an extensive series of documentation and tutorials available in the game itself.  While the animation and the flow of combat feels somewhat limited, the rest of the game creates so many more opportunities for a true sense of adventure and exploration.

reviewText:
The first couple of hours will weed out the people that require instant gratification and put graphics > gameplay, although when you learn how to play the gratification comes steadily and regularly with leveling a multitude of skills and building and maintaining tools.  It's Minecraft with all your favorite mods.  It has incredible depth, length and width.  The graphics are 10 years old but the gameplay is timeless.  Small things like leveling an area for a home or building a fishing rod out of several parts feels like a real accomplishment.  The game is full of probably hundreds of things like that.  The community is extremely helpful and a pleasant place to visit instead of what some forums have turned into.  I don't have the time or desire to write more than this to give my quick thumbs up - time better spent playing the game.

This is not a review but an opinion, and opinions are never wrong just different.  Now I'm off on a grand adventure to craft some nails.

Edit - After 12+ hours on a fresh map mission accomplished.  I have my nails.  After 50+ hours in 10 days I just bought a 3rd copy so we can have our own little family server.  Wonderful game.

Edit - 100+ hours now.  I have my house, the start of an island, a productive mine, planting trees and grass, chain mail and new weapons, founded a settlement (Boatmurdered) and hired 10 Spirit Templars to protect my settlement (and we battled a big troll and hellhound), came across a random family - bull, cow and new calf.  After (or taking a break from) finishing the island will be working on street lamps, storage, furniture, fighting, farming, planting a nearby hill entirely in saplings and whatever else there is to discover.  I should probably take a trip because I've been hanging out in the same ~5% of the map near the starting town in Adventure mode.

reviewText:
I'm going to preface this review with the blunt honesty that this game will not be for everyone.

It has relatively dated looking assets and UI, and an almost crushingly steep learning curve that doesn't ease up within the first few hours of play. In fact, it may seem even MORE daunting after you play for an hour or two. If you've never played a hardcore MMO like Ultima Online or EVE, Wurm may seem frustratingly difficult to get started in. This is not Minecraft (despite Notch having been on the original dev team), nor is it anything like any other relatively casual crafting game.

All of those things being said... It is one of the best crafting RPGs I've ever played, hands down. The seemingly unending complexity, the vast array of items and creatures, the fully moldable landscape, and a skill tree to make an Elder Scrolls game seem casual; Deep hardly begins to describe it. Once you manage to get your hands on the reigns of this game's mechanics... there's no turning back. Suddenly you've carved an entire city into the side of a hill with a growing economy of entirely player controlled mechanics that provides a level of satisfaction unfound in most modern RPGs.

If you're looking for a truly hardcore RPG experience... look no further than Wurm.

reviewText:
So, after much time and consideration, I feel I can write this review with justified opinions. I should state that the majority of my playtime has been spent modding and testing mods, alongside experimenting with different gameplay settings. I have previously played the 'Online' MMO version for some four years pretty solidly (the game encourages recognisable addictive behaviour mechanics, not uncommon for 'grind' MMO's it must be said).

Firstly, this game should not have been released in it's current state. I played WO for years and bought WU in the belief that it was a stand-alone, finished product. It is not. The game is terribly optimised for its level of graphical fidelity, mechanic systems are under constant review and tweaking from the developer, updates threaten to change or undo much of what you assumed was a complete feature or mechanic. What may have passed off as excusable in terms of interface and standards in 2005 is not acceptable here in 2016.

The game, such as it is, has been evolving as an MMO for the best part of 15 years, therefore for the stand-alone version to still be at the stage where features are yet to be completed (or even GUI elements such as icons) is beyond parody. The vanilla gameplay is slow, tedious and dull. The community is small, territorial and fractured. Combat is comcially lacking in player involvement. Modding is unreliable due to continuing development. The visuals are extremely dated, though not unbearable. Audio... I'm not even going to go there.

In this day and age there are far more complete, fun and competent survival games available for a cheaper price. Wurm Unlimited is far too late to the game with such a poor showing. As with the MMO, there was much promise and not enough on delivery.

reviewText:
I have been waiting years for the standalone version of this game, and it's finally here. This game has been about so long parts of the terrain code were written by Notch before he left the project and later created minecraft. You can clearly see the influences that t left on minecraft too. Chopping trees, gaining resources, mining, defending yoursefl from enemies.

The big differences are the 3D graphics, the difficulty, and the levelling. The levelling is fabulously in depth, with over a hundred skills that you can level up. Want to climb a hill? Improve your climbing skill. Want to cook? Improve your cooking skill. Want to cook with dairy? Well, that's a seperate skill. Want to learn the yo-yo? Yep. There's a separate skill for that too.

And the difficultly is insane. The free starter items make it somewhat easier, but you have to craft everything you need, and you have a chance of success. Want to make a mallet? Well, you need to chop a tree down, so that depends on your skill at that, then your skill at making the logs into shafts, the shafts into mallet heads, etc, etc. And if you're not good enough you can mess these steps up. And you can mess up putting the parts together. At low skill there are dozens of ways you can fail.

On top of that, it's one of the few games where you can get properly lost. It avoids the easy You are here" that we're all used to
date: and you just have to remember which way you went. It's incredibly refreshing

reviewText:
Wurm is one of those rare games that makes memories.
I can think back to group activities that took part in from years ago.
In Wurm you really have to really plan every outing.
Who's got the healing covers? ...Who's bringing food and water? ...Which set of armor are you going to wear? ...Are we bringing a wagon?...Does anyone know the way there?
Landscaping and building takes real planning and resource management (not to mention time) but you are rewarded with the ability to make a truly unique (and sometimes beautiful) mark on the land that will stand for ages with upkeep (or slowly fall into ruin with abandonment).
Every aspect of structure and item creation is covered. Make a chest out of pine?  Meh. Make it out of cherry or apple? How nice!
You'll find yourself saving high quality cuts of different woods for specific purposes as you travel through the forest, or snipping sprigs from plants for planting back at home later. Don't get too comfy while you're out there raking your garden though. A young troll might wander out of the woods and turn you into dinner.
Adventuring is really an adventure. Take a wrong turn and you can become fantastically lost.
Wurm is an epic game and the amount of detail is staggering. In my opinion it's second only to Dwarf Fortress in detail.
Since Unlimited relies on private servers, I would stress that one carefully vet a server before committing to play there as weeks of work you put into your home could be undone in seconds by an immature admin. Hope this helps!

reviewText:
I was not even aware this MMO had existed before seeing it here in Steam. I looked into it some more and became intrigued that this is a standalone version with the option of running it as a server for friends  / everyone or as a single player. The age of the game becomes fairly obvious when you see the graphics. They are a bit reminiscent of the earlier Gothic games.  The online game has been around for quite sometime so this is not a total surprise and once you look beyond that you can appreciate the depth there is in terms of content and gameplay. There is a ton of things you can change from the graphics to character levelling. This is a good thing as it means you can tailor the game to be how you want it.

My advice to those new to the game is to play the adventure mode and then speak to the NPC in the middle of the starter town. He will give you missions that will train you on how to do things. It won't take you long before you realise how simple it can be to combine items in order to create new things. The survival elements work well and its pretty easy to find what you need when in the wild. The interface contains a lot of information and its as easy as clicking or dragging to  customise it to your taste.

The levelling system works by increasing your skills the more you use them. This is great because it means your character will develop in style that you play. I'm sure there is many, many things I am yet to discover but so far the game has been both stable and interesting. If you were a fan of the online version then this is a no brainer. If not then still consider this because if you play with friends you can become the gamesmaster and weave events in the game. There is a creative mode as well for those who would rather spend their time building.

reviewText:
This is only my second review since joining Steam.  I’m new and more than a bit shy so I tend to stay quiet but I can’t remain that way when it comes to Wurm Unlimited.

I have been an avid RPer/MMO fan since the first version of Everquest and Asheron’s Call.  I worked on more than one game as a concept artist and graphic designer when the first big name MMO’s came into existence yet still, I have never found the game for me.  SWG was close until … well anyone who played it knows that hellish tale of woe.  When I could no longer find a complex game that offered world building and sandbox appeal, I went to Second Life.  I became a professional builder and even a GM for Linden Labs but I missed the old MMO’s.  Wurm helped me recapture that era once more.

First, let me say this right up front, the game still needs work.  There are a few bugs that I am hoping they iron out someday and the graphics have glitches that need tweaking.  Considering that I am into graphic design, that’s probably just my O.C.D. kicking in.  I see a skin that doesn’t quite meet up correctly and my eye twitches.  The combat is awkward and the game itself doesn’t just have a learning curve, it has a learning cliff.  Please warn your friends not to give up too soon before they enter this game or you'll never hear the end of it.

I have fallen in love with this game.  The depth of realism in the crafting and survival is amazing.  You walk into the world and in order to survive, you have to create everything from scratch but the way its set up makes sense.  If you want to fish, you need to make yourself a fishing pole.  You carve a fish hook or make it from iron you mined.  You create your own fishing line from cotton you gathered growing wild in the fields and you whittled the pole from branches of a fallen log.  From the smallest task like just finding enough food to eat to survive the winter or picking the right herbs to heal your wounds, all the way to creating a vast settlement with your friends, this game has it all.

I was so impressed with the depth and freedom of the game that I have purchased a server and I’m hosting an RP world with some friends.  We are currently rebuilding the settlement towns and this reminds me so much of when I used to buy an island in SL and build a world for people to come RP in.  The best part is, instead of $150.00 a month, this island cost me a one-time fee of $30 bucks.  With the ability to mod and improve the graphics myself or with the help of others, this is the game world I have longed to play in.

Now if you’ll excuse me, I am going to cut this short and head back in game.  If you see my husband, tell him I love him but I have so much to do…  so much to build...

reviewText:
I've played Wurm Online for years. When I first heard of this coming out, I got it for pre-order because it's everything I wanted. It was Wurm Online without being public, I can do anything without harming anyone, and thats how I wanted it.

** You can edit skill modifiers, so the game can be grindy, or not grindy.
I like it kind of in between, because I get appreciation when I build a house with low skills.
** You can be GM and change the world whatever you want. Fly! Even seasons & weather change daily.
** You can mod your world.
I have a custom map at the moment, I created it with a generator and plopped it in game.
(Photo below.)
https://67.media.tumblr.com/974ac9faaa8a636b5693eca3f2c58153/tumblr_o7p65xEFve1sd1k09o1_1280.png
** You can play offline or online, and you do not need to PVP anyone. No looters! Unless you want them!
** You don't like walking? Build a boat! Big or small, you can go for it. Don't like boats? Ride a horse, or better yet, ride a crocodile, because you can DO that ♥♥♥♥.
** Wanna play as a theif? Adventure mode has a few buildings scattered around, learn your lockpicking skills and break open the doors. I had THIEVERY as my affinity and it was grand watching my skill shoot up when I opened chests.
**Get your friends together, you can build houses and castles, and farms.
** Make armor, farms, raise sheep, cows and horses, even firey hell horses!

Since there are no trolls unless you wanna play public, playing privately is a blast with friends.
I have no regrets getting this standalone version, except maybe that they need to add more furniture, but that's coming!

reviewText:
There's something about Wurm, once it gets it's hooks in you it won't let go.

Wurm Unlimited offers a new experience though, your own world, new and untouched, with the ability to build your own custom lands, and explore, build, battle, survive, and create.

Graphically, Wurm is not up there with the biggest and best, but after a while, the graphics don't matter, you're immersed in your world, changing the very shape of the land, digging, levelling and moving the very dirt under your feet, shaping the rocks, mining deep and vast caverns to get at the ores, growing your food, tending your animals, and fighting off the beasts who want you dead.

This isn't just Wurm, it's Wurm your way, set up your server, make it easy, or hard, set it up for survival, or building, you choose, because it's not Wurm Online anymore, now it's also Unlimited, and it's only going to get better, with Mods and Tools to enhance your gameplay.

I now played this game for some time and I played WO in the past, but never really liked it due to the subscription and the really low skillgain.

I think I made the right decision when I joined one of the bigger servers after a friend recommended it and had really no issue with the people on it. Yes there can be idiots, but you find them in all survival-ish and sandboxy games with community driven servers.

reviewText: After years of playing repeating MMOs (grind grind grind) My friends and I finally found a game that put the adventure back. This game gives you nothing, you will have to earn it. It's not that hard to figure out and you will love the rewards x10 compared to the other games that are now days making it to easy. No you wont get to power level. You cant buy your way in. Your gonna get dropped into a world face first with a compass and a few supplies to get you by. Its getting dark outside so you better run to a city. But wait, you hear a wolf growl from the bushes, you start to run but you are bitten in the leg. Turning your back WU gives the wolf a advantage since you turned. Secondly it not just , you took 23 damage please heal, oh no its WAY more detailed. Your gonna need to find some cotton and bandage that wound. But it also depends on where the wound is and what type. You see your right leg is bleeding out and infection is sure to come. This game is ok on graphics and fighting, but the hidden treasure is in the details. Theres a skill for everything you can think of, sometimes  branches of 2 to 3 skills for one thing. Anytime you make something, your skill effects the quality. You got to get to know people and trade, because you dont have npc shops that sell stuff, only venders owned by players. I'll have to say I am alittle spooked sometimes, the game seems to have some witchcraft in it. It has gods to choose from, altars, animal sacrificing,ect. You can also breed animals, groom them, tame them, sell them, eat them, ride them. Any trade you can think of is in the game and broken down into many parts and it wont be easy. But after you put in the time to be the best at that niche people start coming to you and buying. I went from rock bottom to having a nice little town in about 3 weeks. But in that time I dug dug and dug and my friends dug and we sold the dirt to some rich guy down the street. He needs the dirt for building. We started out with a little hand cart that carried 40 dirt a trip. After becoming friends with the guy, he built us a large cart and then a wagon capable of hauling 3600 dirt. We bought some land and hired some guards that now run around and kill those wolfs. I'd have to call it more of a simulator then a game. It could use some work on the graphics end, but im thinking thats why I dont have hardly any lag issues. I also don't see alot of bugs. Yeah there must be a few, but for all the stuff thats going on in this game they have really put alot of work into making it solid.

reviewText:
The complexity of the crafting system and game mechanics in general, are everything the reviews tell you- prepare for a steep learning curve. It personally took me 3 days just to understand the basics(though I did this casually).

But If you can get passed the dated graphics, awkward UI(this is subjective), and steep learning curve(not subjective lol), you will discover a game where you... watch a progress bar half the time. Yet it is strangely addicting, immersive and even fun. I guess it is very peaceful, just minding yourself in the woods, building your little hut or digging to find that damn iron vein, while the ambient sounds of the enviroment immerse you in the world of Wurm.

The freedom the game gives you is unparalleled in my gaming experience. And I can say the same for the complexity and sheer variety of the crafting system. All this just adds to the immersion. Wurm is a harsh a tedious world, but that just makes the pay off that much more rewarding- I've never been so happy to complete a virtual 1x1 little wooden hut.

8/10(disregarding the dated graphics and UI because the game is over 10 years old, but 7/10 for those who really care about that)

reviewText:
20 Hours in and still going, so I guess that's a good sign.

If you're like me, you've always been interested in Wurm Online but never got into it because of the excessive grindyness and extremely slow pace. Wurm Unlimited allows the hosting of private servers, meaning skill values, action timers,  and skillup rates can all be adjusted. With the addition of mod support, which is still in it's early stages at this point, the game could finally get to a point where I'd actually find it fun.

If you're unsure about buying this game, don't. Try the free MMO version, Wurm Online, first. It will give you an idea of how the basic game plays. From there you can easily figure what kind of changes you'd like to see in a server of your own in Wurm Unlimited.

reviewText: Thanks to this I can play Wurm again. It's a perfect solution for people who don't want to pay the monthly subscription and giving people the ability to run their own servers fixes the problems that Wurm Online had. The majority of the servers speed up the xp and building rate which is a god send since Wurm Online's xp rate was deathly slow which probably killed off the playerbase in the first place. And speaking of playerbase you now actually do have a ton of people playing. There are servers that have at least 100 people playing which really is a good amount for this type of game. Though I'm not sure if new players would enjoy this since the whole game is literally just grinding. But it's about the joy of progression and watching everything slowly coming together. It's just a good comfy game that you can multitask while playing. For Wurm Online players it's a must get and for non-Wurm Online players I would say it's worth a shot.

reviewText: This is not an easy game. It was never meant to be easy. But if you have the patience to learn, you'll be privy to the deepest sandbox experience available. There's a skill for everything: everything from bladesmithng and weapons head smithing, to toy making. You can change the land by terraforming... or sail to distant ones. Have the winds turn against you and be forced to tack to get where you are going. Build a bridge to nowhere or just explore what is around you already.\n\nIn Wurm you can interact with everything-water, the dirt, that bush, using either a right click menu, a selection bar, or many hundreds of hotkeys. This means that your looking" has to be bound to the left mouse button. Many people are upset about this
date: and call it "clunky." Minecraft doesn't have this problem
recommended: they say. But Minecraft is a simple game
hoursPlayed: with only a few interactions: take
voteText: swing tool/weapon
helpfulPercent: fill bucket. But in Wurm you have literally hundreds of things you can do to tiles
votesHelpful: objects
votesTotal: creatures
votesFunny: and plants depending on what you have active. This takes some getting used to
commentsCount: and there is no way you can get used to it in an hour.\n\nMy point is this: when people compain about the "UI" or "player interaction
column16:
they are actually complaining about the game's COMPLEXITY. They want a casual game, and Wurm is simply not that.

Regardless! You don't have to pay a thing to try Wurm! If you are still concerned about the game's complexity (pointed to as a flaw by haters), or If you are not sure if it's for you, you may want to try the free version, just do a search for Wurm Online. Keep in mind, though, that WO is much slower paced than WU, but it will give you a good idea if it's for you.

Things to consider:
1. Combat in this game is in the style of Dungeons & Dragons. That is, it is die roll based. Monsters are provided to add additional challenges to your exploration, but this is primarily a crafting/exploring game. Some have described it as more of a Medieval simulator.

2. If you play the slow version, it's important to know why it's slow. It's to encourage you to work as a team. This is to encourage realistic behavior in the players. Building a whole settlement should be a daunting task, and it is. If you decide to do it, you might get frustrated, but there is nothing like the feeling of finishing a grand building. The old expression is true: frustration fuels triumph.

3. Not everything is completely realistic, but it would be almost impossible to have complete realism. Digging fencepost holes is no fun. What Wurm does, rather, is attempt to give the *feeling* of doing it without taking you through every single step.

NB: This is a rough draft and shall be expanded.

reviewText:
Do you want to play a game about life in the fantasy middle ages with dragons, boats, magic, settlement building, and farming? Wurm Unlimited is for you.

The game consists of building your skills in whatever disciplines you want like:
Farming
Mining
Fishing
Fighting
Tailoring
Cooking
Milking
Yo-yo-ing
And many more!

You also build up your home with reshaping the land, searching for resources, and building your home.

The game can be played single player but I highly recommend looking for a multi-player server on the Wurm Forums.

If you don't play with faster skill gain and action speed the game is really slow and grindy. Try finding a server with fast settings!

reviewText:
I have been playing Wurm Online off and on for a few years now. I believe this game is one of the most in depth sandbox survival games there is and perhaps ever will be. Wurm may not have the most up to date graphics but for what it lack in graphics it makes up for in depth. This game is for people who are looking for a more in depth game experience, chopping a tree  may take a few strikes with your axe and therefore take a moment to cut down but the game was shooting for more realism in that aspect and because of the time it takes to actually build things and gather the resources required to build things it makes it far more rewarding when you have completed building something. There are a bunch of people out there that need that instant gratification as in Minecraft, and yes I love Minecraft as well but this game gives you a more rewarding feel than that instant gratification. I have played some of the other survival games here on steam and none of them really compare to this one.

-	For those of you that say the Servers do not work I haven’t had one single issue with this at all.
-	 I like this version as it is a breath of fresh air to try to impose new game rules for servers than the ones we have all grown used to
-	If you love a challenge this is the game for you and you will be rewarded
-	If you are looking for instant gratification then just don’t get this game
-	There is a wurmpedia online that will help with many details about the game if you are stuck in anyway.
-	All in all so far I have not ran into any issues to speak of.
-	And most importantly this is a great game and a completed game unlike many games on Steam
-	If you are willing to give the game a little bit of your time you will find that it will draw you in.

reviewText:
This game combined a bunch of elements that I really liked. It gave you the building and terraforming ability of Minecaft, the POTENTIAL (we'll get to this in a minute) ability to work together with friends, and a leveling-by-using skill system. So, you can build your own hideaway, town, or whatever, you still have to survive (and stuff in here's deadly!), and you forge your own path on what you're going to develop.

BUT. Frickin' but. We have tried, so very hard, my friends and I, to host a server and have them see it, and to have them run a server so we can see it. We're no slouches in hosting servers. We cannot see each other, and the boards seem to suggest this is a real craps shoot. That's not how multiplayer and servers should be.

Because it takes out the interactive element that really makes it enjoyable, for now, I cannot recommend this game. I may change it if Wurm takes steps to address this.

reviewText:
Wow, when i heard about that title and read some details i was hyped. Loving the idea and playing it however are 2 very different things.

So in short i went from hyped to desperately wanting to get rid of it in a matter of 1.5 hours of trying it. Here is why:

Graphics are ugly but i could deal with it if the rest was nice enough
World interaction is clumsy and boring, its menus over menus over menus, clicking repeatedly an action to cut 1 single tree ergo boooooring
Interacting with NPCs is unintuitive and feels disconnected. Everything happens in a chat and in a status window. Other games solve that much more intruiging and engaging.
Now for technical problems: i do have a rather big 4K Monitor and the UI for this just released title cant handle it. Its unreadably small, and even though text size can be changed it helps nothing, nada, niente...(nice feature btw: here change your font size user...result: just kiddiiiiing...)
Slowpaced and boring, getting into the game just doesnt feel like i am the one doing stuff and dont get me even started on the fighting. Whoever invented that system must be out of work and bored to death with the rest of his life so he can enjoy sitting in front of a young chicken for 5 minutes while you exchange attacks with it. Comeon a freakin chicken takes 5 minutes to kill with a sword? really?
Nothing is intuitive, you have to guess what you can do. Wanna do something with that nice piece of wood you got there? Well figure it out which of your numerous tools does what to it, try and error. This could be done so much easier but i guess Wurm just loves its deep textmenu interaction style.
0/10 would never attack a chicken with a sword again and waste 5 minutes of my life waiting for it to die while receiving numerous wounds. da ♥♥♥♥?!?!

reviewText:
So, as a long time Wurm Online player, I saw several issues in WO that bothered me - but not a whole lot could be done about it. What Code Club AB / Rolf says goes, and that's sad because there's a lot more to this game that could be there and arguably should be but isn't.
This is the answer, and is definitely worth playing if you either A) know how to host a server, use all the tools and mods at your disposal (or create your own, even better) to make it something that's not just worth playing but a GREAT game, or B) know a server that does that all.
I play on Razor's Edge and I'm extremely pleased with it. Frankly I'd pay the sub fee for WO if Rolf was more like Razor; but I'm looking at WU as being Razor's Edge buy-to-play. Great staff, lots of cool stuff going on in the background, fantastic map design, quests, treasure and dungeons and such.. it's pretty ridiculous. If you're interested in checking that out, go take a look at http://razors-edge.enjin.com/ - whatever links and info you might want is pretty readily accessible there and at the forums (add forum to the end of that link).

But I've also played on my own server, hosted by a professional server hosting company, with a friend.
Wurm is for a certain kind of person, and though that niche is very small, it's definitely holding me through while I wait for Chronicles of Elyria.

Wurm Unlimited was the move that Code Club AB needed to make. It is what you make of it. If you have the thirty to spare, and don't mind basically playing a MUD/MUSH game with graphics, give this a shot.

Seriously this game has an enormous amount of depth. The learning curve is immense, and Wurmpedia is your friend. I play on a server with a higher skill start, 5x action times, 2x experience and it still takes a while to accomplish anything grand. After about 50 hours I have a small wooden house with a bed, some strorage bins/chests, all of the essential iron tools and just started working on a mine of my own. It's not a game for people looking for quick satisfaction, but if you enjoy the struggle then this game is for you.

reviewText:
I find this game to be a fun and relaxing way to spend a few hours.  Well 175 hours as I write this review.
It does take a bit of time to figure out how to achieve things but after a while you soon get it and find yourself enjoying the experience.

I find that treating this as a game where you spend time initially surviving and then finding yourself thriving as you build your home / village up and spend time making various items and improving the quality of them as high as you can so you can sell them to the traders scattered around.

The silver you make will then be enough money to pay for your deed and guards, if you have any, and then to keep paying the upkeep costs of the deed as, if you fail to do this, your village will eventually disband and decay away if you dont manage to keep up with the payments.  This wont happen too quickly though if you do find youself away for a while.

There is combat as well, both against the animals and other various creatures in the environment as well as other people if you venture onto the pvp lands.  Its a bit you hit them then they hit you but your clothing / armour / weapons and elevation etc all help to decide the result of these battles.   You can normally get to pvp enabled lands via a boat from the pve lands so whatever your prefered gamestyle there is something here to suit you.  Having said that the pve area's tend to have the most people playing .  I think f you approach this in the right way through then pvp its a fun diversion and a good use for all that armour and weaponry you will have built for yourself.

I guess this wont be for everyone, but if you are unsure then trying out wurm online itself is free up to level 20 on your skills.  If you want to get those skills to 99 though you will either need to buy this version for a one time fee and play on the free servers (or create your own) - Unlimited tends to be a slightly speeded up version of the game as your skills can increase more rapidly and other actions like growing crops can be speeded up.

Or if you want the full experience then subscribe to wurm online itself.  Its been going over 10 years and has a loyal following.

Overall I find this to be good fun.  I am going to log in again myself now and work on improving the cloth puppet toys I am making.  I find they normally sell quite well if they are high enough quality.... then I guess the pigs will need tending.... I also need more iron.... see ya!

reviewText:
Pre-dating Minecraft and most other sandbox games, Wurm is a remarkably deep and broad sandbox game that does not treat the fast-food game-play entertainment market kindly at all.

Every element of this sandbox is not only challenging, but provides a real sense of accomplishment to those that are looking for a long-term sandbox game; not a fleeting experience.

The survival system is complex and very reasonable, the crafting system is deep and complex enough to keep a sandbox enthusiast very engaged and interested.  You can claim property, tame wild-life, farm, and build a village to a city with impunity; anything from boats, ships, transportation carts, pavement, defenses, tools, weapons, armor, houses, etc.
One might be initially mentally blocked due the graphics, but if you put deep and rich game-play and game-play mechanics ahead of that, then this is worth the look.

Many very dedicated private server owners are ex-Wurm Online players, and they are there for the long-term.

reviewText:
I give it 10/10

First, I want to say who this game is NOT for. If you are impatient or like things done quickly, this game is not for you. By design everything takes time to do, and that is what makes it rewarding.

Wurm Online is one of the best sandbox games in the world, but I am one who does not like monthly subscription fees and believes that players should be the ones to host servers. For me Wurm Unlimited is a step in the right direction. The dedicated server was surprisingly easy to get set up and I had mine up and running about 45 minutes after the game launched on steam.

The actual gameplay is just as slow as Wurm Online, this is a plus in my book, but can be tweeked to speed up the skill rates. The game runs smoother than I was expecting and I have not had any real issues with it at all. If you are looking for a game in which you feel like you are actually building a house wooden plank by wooden plank, this is your best option. It is also great for those who like PvP or fighting powerfull monsters.

reviewText:
Most likely the leading example of an open world sandbox experience. I have played the online version for many many years and have never lost interest.

Pros:

Nearly endless possibilities for creativity.
Work at your own pace even more so now with a standalone version.
Customized private servers for a totally unique gaming experience every server you go to.
The ability to teraform the entire world around you either alone or with a massive community in dedicated servers.
Create a world around you with complete control over how it looks and feels.
The list could go on for days.....

Cons:

Lack of animation in some areas.
Somewhat slow paced gameplay and combat for those that are used to other titles.
Rediculously hard to learn if you don't know where to look for guides (Servers will help you learn the game!)
Typical Online multiplayer issues.
It's based on a Java engine.

All in all, you take it with it's flaws and realize just what kind of limitless possibilites it has the ability to grow into.

4000+ Hours on Wurm Online

Review of the Unlimted Version

________________________________________


This is not a walk in the palk, however. Wurm Unlimited provides you the tools to make it so. Make it as hard or as easy as you like, it's the standalone game without any subscription to pass level 20 in skills, nor is there any way to purchase in game coin, unless the server you play on enables a way.

I reccomend this game only if you have a group of people to play with. 3+ should be good.

Think of this game as an extremely intricate minecraft like game. The literal definition of Survival.

If you can Get past the graphics, you'll find an extremely addicting and rewarding game with mystical creatures to slay or tame, form alliances and kingdoms and wage war between each other.

The combat system is a little... complicated". It'll take you a while to understand how everything works in Wurm but don't fret
date:
the wiki is there to help and will explain everything.


Take your time
recommended: don't rush. Find some friends and get wurming <3\n\nI also
hoursPlayed: reccomend joining "Primordial - Tranquility".  You'll see me and a few other people setting up a kingdom of our own and we're willing to help out anyone who passes by!\n"

reviewText: I played Wurm Online years ago and was overjoyed when it finally came to Steam as a stand alone client with user run servers. I'm hosting one and really enjoy it. You can tweak the server so it's not so much of a grind and whatever updates Wurm Online gets, Wurm Unlimited gets also. It may look a bit dated, but you're free to build and craft an terraform to your hearts content. I'm focusing on farming and cooking while other players on my server focus on combat or smiting.\nIt should be noted that the best way to play this game is not solo, it's with other players. The focus on community is key in a great Wurm experience.

reviewText:
I wrote my initial review on March 7th, 2016, with 14 hours in-game time.  It is now March 12th, 2016 and I have 56 hours under my belt.  Here's what I've learned...

* Wurm Unlimited (which is based on the Wurm Online MMORPG) is a masterpiece of a game.
* It hands nothing to you (except basic tools).  You must work for everything.
* Something you think will take 5 minutes ends up being 4 hours, because you can't stop playing.
* Looting is a non-issue on servers that don't allow thievery.  Lock your stuff up and it's safe.
* It's a massive game world.  You can go anywhere.
* The world is so beautiful and the landscape so extreme that you'll be in awe time and again.
* The graphics settings available are insane.  You can adjust everything.  I cranked it with my 970 GTX.
* The game loads quick and it runs great.

This game is something you can really sink your teeth into and take your time.  It's so rich in depth.  You'll be finding hidden gems (game mechanics) that'll blow your mind; that they thought to add such things into the game.

Coming from almost 500 hours in Rust and being tired of the same old formula (build up, log off, come back later to find you've been looted to oblivion), Wurm Unlimited is like a breath of fresh air.

Word to the wise.  If you're expecting instant gratification, don't buy this game.  If you're not ready to put long hours into Wurm, this game isn't for you.  There is no one to hold your hand.

However, if you're looking for a meat and taters and seconds... no... heapin' helpins... aw hell, the whole cow and the whole potato field, this game is for you.

UPDATE:  I've now spent 245 hours in Wurm Unlimited.  I have my own settlement (Perry on Mythmoor).  The depth of the game is such that it still has much to reveal for me. I'm reaching halfway on my skill levels (50) and I have only scratched the surface.  If you give it a chance, you'll find it addicting and a pure joy to play.  Since everyone is on the server for enjoyment, most are friendly and helpful and become your (new) friends and neighbors; socializing happens naturally.  I assume I'll be spending another 245 hours in Wurm Unlimited.  Probably way more.  In a nutshell, BUY IT!.  Still on the fence?  Look at my screenshots, watch some videos first.

Wurm Unlimited is like a sponge, it'll sap your life from you.  The real world will cease to exist or at the very least become a haze you walk through to get to your next login.

reviewText:
So i don't write many reviews out of laziness but i want to express how much i actually love this game.

i have played many many hours of this game both the wurm online version and wurm unlimited and even though it is tedious at times everything feels worth it and you feel proud of what you do because it's so tedious. Everything in this game requires a lot of time to do and once you finally get it done you feel like you accomplished something big. This game allows you do do anything you want in the best way possible. You could be an adventurer and find rare artifacts or fight hard monsters and dragons. You could be a carpenter and make the biggest houses on the server. You could be a blacksmith and make legendary swords and armor that everyone will want to buy from you. anything is possible in the game and I love it for that.

TLDR; This game is amazing, if you want a game where you can do anything you want in a sandbox enviroment with a little outdated graphics (graphics don't make a game) but with absolute freedom, this is the game for you.

reviewText:
Having played Wurm Online (WO) since 2009 I am very familiar with how things work in Wurm. So I did not encounter a learning curve when I tried Wurm Unlimited (WU). So for me the transition was smooth and effortless. The rewards I saw for stepping into WU where everywhere, beginning with modifiable skill gain helping to make the advancement of skills easier all the way to having ultimate GM powers. The server setup was simple and intuitive in my opinion. There is currently a lot of forum activity and advice if you do get stuck and need help. The overall WU experience was extremely positive for me.

That being said, Wurm is truthfully not for everyone, but for those that can get by the learning curve of the vast crafting system and want to create a world around you from your own imagination the rewards are great. Now with WU you can play with friends or decide to go it alone. Like I said before the extensive Wurm community is there to help when you need it or you can try working things out on your own if you enjoy more of a challenge.

I cannot say enough about this game, challenging, addicting, rewarding, seemingly limitless ability to create and change the world to suit your own pleasure. I would highly recommend this game to anyone that wants to create and build, explore (careful out there, you could get eaten) or just rest and relax in the ambiance of your own created village, Wurm has it all if you are willing to spend some time to find it.

My recommendation would be if you are unsure of whether this game is for you, try it first with Wurm Online, it is free to play. That way you get a feel of what Wurm has to offer before you jump in and buy it.

reviewText: I bought Wurm Unlimited 2 weeks ago, approximately. Since then I've built a mansion, planted acres of crops, and run from some trolls (the green kind, not the internet kind). If you like being rewarded for your hard work, you will be sucked in to Wurm. You could become a renowned blacksmith, or a master carpenter, or simply a labourer working to pay your keep. You could become a great chef, who serves his catch of the day with potatoes and rice grown in his garden. You could become a lumberjack, living in solitude deep in the woods, growing all manner of trees in her groves. You could become a devout priest to your god, provinding blessings and curses for the right coin. You could become an architect, not just of structures, but of the very earth itself. Or you could be all of these things and more. You have total control over the world, it's up to you to chose what to do with it.

reviewText: If you are trying to decide between this game and Life is Feudal, choose this, it does have a huge learning curve but when you fully understand the game, it becomes one of the most addicting games you can find. One of the original devs was Notch from Minecraft and this is kinda like that but not voxel and it has physics with a fully editable enviroment, You can make custom maps if you want your own server and the map size on the server I play on, let's just say it is a 5 hour round trip from spawn and back to my house by boat. Sure the graphics are a bit dated but the game originally came out in 2006ish as Wurm Online and was an MMORPG but the game has been given a few new graphics and when you buy Wurm Unlimited you get the whole game with no monthly payment. The game has so much more to offer than most game of this type when you get into it and if you don't believe me, look on Wurmpedia and see all the aspects that go into the game. This game also has next to no bugs and works great, also remember to edit your graphics for a better looking game in the menu. I would rate 10/10.

reviewText: I loved wurm online since Golden Valley and played through a few other servers too then took a break as I was just playing this game all the time. I am now back with Wurm Unlimited and I must say I have missed this game. I have searched for other sand box games and this is only one that has ever satisfied all the things I want to do. Dying in a remote forest after going on a hunt and losing all my best gear as I couldn't find my body is still one of my most memorable moments. This game is so huge and so real in terms of its medieval setting that I had no map and had no way of locating my body. Seems harsh but then this game doesn't hold your hand. You get a small helping hand for a day or so and then you are truly on your own. No other game comes close to how this game makes you feel (and I have looked). When you succeed at anything in this game you feel a true level of accomplishment.

reviewText: I have never played Wurm Online so I can't compare and contrast it, however, I love the building tools Wurm Unlimited offers. reviewText:
Okay so ive played 55h in total (and WO hours) and i can honestly say... this game is awesome

First of first it may not be a noob-friendly game because it really hard for newcomers and forever alones (playing this game alone is hard and dumb). Ppl are afraid of that interface but its really intuitive and not that complicated at all. You will get to know and live with it after few hours. Also, it needs time, a lot of time. You make tons of actions in-game (you can check it in options -> statistics) and every action have its own time needed. But its beautiful in that game.

Yeah game is about clicking, you click there - make action, click here - make action. Yes but look what  you build, all world is builded by players. Isn't that amazing ? After building your first house (in few first days or if ure interlligent enough in one day) you'll feel very proud of yourself.

Pros:
- Immersive and unique gameplay
- Many skills that are needed in some actions
- Good crafting system and a lot of items
- Big world builded only by players
*(Not on every server, it depends) You can sail between PvE and PvP island, good idea
Cons:
-Fighting is skill-based and thats a bit boring
-Not noob-friendly (cuz so many things to do, thats obvious but some may say it as a cons)
- TOOK MY LIFE!

10/10 would die by a landshark again

DO IT, JUST DO IT, BUY IT

reviewText:
Wurm online gave me thousands of hours worth of play, when i tell you that if this game clicks with you it can become an addiction, beleive me.

I'm suprised that it's not mentioned this game was originally developed by Rolf from Code Club (current), and Notch of Mojang (who later founded Minecraft). If your a fan of minecraft you may very well enjoy this game, especially now the unlimited version is out.

Though the unlimited version allows single play i would highly suggest playing with friends, i had alot of fun over the years playing the original online game from starting with some freinds and building up our own meager little place, and having to avoid the wildlife who will eat your face if it gets half a chance, to building large towns, mines and terraforming projects and organising dragon hunts when found.

Do not however beleive that this game is perfect. You WILL find it clunky, you WILL find it outdated. you will find 100 other things than annoy the hell out of you...yet if this game clicks with you, you will play it regardless and adore it.

reviewText: Wurm Unlimited. If you want to start building a castle and be done in a few hours, this game is not for you. If you however like to invest time into a game because you enjoy the satisfaction of working hard on something and enjoying the fruits of your labor than this game is perfect for you. Here is an example of building the most basic of carts to haul your stuff around.First you have to cut trees down and chop them into logs. Then you have to use carving knives and saws and hatchets to make all the parts. You have to make each wheel, finish the wheel with wooden shafts and planks. Then you have to attach the 2 wheels together on an axel. Then you have to craft the body of the cart by making wooden pegs and planks and shafts and putting them all together in the right order. Some parts may need to be built alone and then attached. After its finished you can improve its overall quality with tools like files and pelts. My first cart took a few days to make. I would recommend this game to anyone not looking for a high paced building sim. I have never found a game so detailed in the things that must be done to survive.\n\nI played wurm online for a while and decided it was just to much money to spend every month. Then you have the pressure of either playing or wasting your monthly fee. This works the way minecraft works in that you buy the game and host your own server or join someone else's server. There is a list of servers running so it is easy to join a server already running. If you want to play with lots of people on the official wurm servers you have to get Wurm Online and pay monthly.

reviewText:
The dream came true, finally we can manage the server of the game that we love so much.
Come and enjoy the best crafting sandbox game in steam.
It will only get better.
But if you are totally new to Wurm, be ready for the curve. It is steep, even a lot of things are hard for us the Wurm Online vets, like playing as a GM.
There is a great deal of trolls, true, but there  is a bunch of players/devs working really hard, listening and applying fixes and features as soon as they can do it.
You can hang around with other players in the IRC that is integrated with the game. Maybe even get some answers for your questions, but please, again, the learning curve is really steep, you will need the help of the guides being published here or reading some in the wiki : wurmpedia.com and the official forums. I'm running my server fully loaded of animals and is running better than a WO official server. That good.

No time to write anymore, My cows are waiting

reviewText:
This game is a lot of fun and very immersive. It is extremely realistic and offers a lot of fun to those that like Minecraft and playing other RPGs like Runescape etc.

One thing I will mention is that it is quite slow paced. even with adjustments to the settings, you won't find yourself building a house for a while. You first need to find Iron and other materials which can be a real pain. Don't download this game if you are inpatient or if you're expecting to be able to create a city immediately. Download this game if you're prepared for the possibility that you might not even build the first wall of your house for the first 10-15 hours.

Definitely recommend for anyone patient enough!

reviewText:
What can I say about Wurm Unlimited?
I`ve only played 179 hours (at the time of writing this so I`m not that far in the game jet, but wow, this game got some serious depth to it.
The graphics look good, but both the crafting system and the UI is something to get used to for sure, but once you do get used to it there is nothing to complain about. And whatever you do, whatever project you start it will feel slow as  heck in the beginning but it WILL get faster and better as you level up your skills, and when you finally finish the project, big or small you will feel rewarded for all that hard labour.

My plus & minuses:

+ Nice graphics.
+ Deep crafting and skill system.
+ Great community (best I`ve ever experienced) (server).
+ thousands of things to craft and even more to do.
+ And so much more!

- Animations are getting old.
- Can be a bit repetitive.
- UI looks to be from the 80`s.

All-in-all a great game worth every cent!
If you want a game you can play for months on end this game is for you! It is truly a gem of a game! I`m on the Sklotopolis [PVE] server as Wadena if you want to contact me there, feel free to do so, maybe I can help you get started. Hope to see you there!

This is a game that give you the option of playing on the server of other player who bought the game before you and chose to shear it with other players (no password server),  those who want the world to them self, or for just them and a few selected friends have passwords. When choosing a server the name/ description sometimes let you know what to expect example ( PvP, Pve, 5x exp...) keep in mind that the owner have control of the setting so expect anything. reviewText:
First off, I will say that this game is not for everyone, and If you have never played Wurm Online, then I'd recommend to try it before you think about buying Wurm Unlimited.

I started playing Wurm Online sometime in late 2009/early 2010, and I loved it. However, I did think the grind was a bit too harsh, and eventually I couldn't afford to pay for premium anymore, so I quit playing. I moved on to other games, the most similar being minecraft, but nothing ever came close to Wurm for me, so I ended up logging back in every few months/years to see what's changed, but never sticking around for long because I couldn't get premium.

Now they have released Wurm Unlimited, a stand-alone, one-time payment version of the MMO, and needless to say, I was really looking forward to getting it. It's basically what I've always wanted Wurm to be, a one-time payment version that lets you do everything the game has to offer without limitation, and even lets you play on other people's servers, or even your own.

Now I guess I'll put a list of Pros/Cons.

Pros:
1. A true Sandbox game that lets you do whatever you want, wherever you want, now at your own pace since you can modify the speed at which you do things and gain skill levels.
2. Everything is made by the players.
3. Hundreds of different skills and thousands of items you can craft.
4. Maps can be gigantic, don't expect to see many people come to visit you if you manage to build somewhere on the other side of the map :P.

Cons:
1. Very large learning curve, this game is NOT noob friendly, this may be a pro to some, but if you expect to have you hand held, you will be dissapointed (unless you get into a nice village that will help you out).
2. Graphics are pretty dated, though you can still find some places with beautiful views.
3. Still has a few bugs, I haven't run across anything game breaking though, mostly just stuff to do with animations and stuff.
4. Not sure if a bug or not, but as of the time of this review, you can't play without internet access. It isn't a big deal for most, but some people may be thinking of buying this so they can play when they are without an internet connection. As of right now, you cannot.


So, if you tried Wurm Online and liked it, but thought the grind was too painful, don't want/can't pay for premium, or you just don't like MMO's and jsut want to play by yourself or with close friends, then you will most likely enjoy Wurm Unlimited. If you have NOT played Wurm Online, and Wurm Unlimited sounds interesting to you, please try Wurm Online first, it's free to try out. Don't complain in the forums or something about it cause you bought the game without researching it.
voteText: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
To WO players:
If you have played Wurm Online you need no introduction. Unlimited allows you to do everything WO does at whatever server settings you please.

To new players:
This is a game of years. Pay once play forever. It's hard to describe Wurm but, if you are the type of person who is tired of arcadey games that quickly lose meaning, give this a try. If you think this game is too grindy, remember, it's all about how you play. There are so many things to do and you choose the settings to play them at. This is the whole point of WU. Your settings, your enjoyment.

The dedicated server is really light weight, and has a GUI to set everything up. Give this game a chance it will grow on you.

Game mechanic settings:
PvP - yes
Skillgain - 1x
Characteristics start at 20
Fighting starts at 5
All other skills start at 1
Combat rating - 1x
Action timers - 1.4x (subject to change)
Upkeep is enabled
Free deeds are disabled
Minimum mining actions - 40
Breeding modifier - 1x
Field growth - 8 hours
Tree spread - 1x

I personally don't care much about the skill gaining but it's just somthing to work towards when you have nothing to do.

reviewText:
Currently, we are running a modified version of Wurm Unlimited. (Soon to be a heavily modified version). This is the first step in creating a game that Razor and various friends have been working toward for over 10 years. Although the game is based on WU, at some point it will no longer be Wurm as many know it, but will become Ages of Urath.

This will be an ongoing migration, and will not happen all at once. There will not be a server wipe to create Ages of Urath.

Ages of Urath will include political, economic, religious, warfare and lore systems that don't exist in Wurm, or really in any other game today. It is intended to be the richest online gaming experience possible.

Ages of Urath is about people and the stories that they make. The game design will support this by providing mechanics that bring people together, to get them interested in some common goals, to scare them, delight them, ♥♥♥♥ them off, get them riled up, make them laugh, and watch some of them overcome all obstacles and succeed in ways they never expected.
Great solid code, easy to mod engine.   Able to create massive multi map worlds.     We love it!!
www.razors-edge.org
